title: WE WANT SOLO QUEUE!
body:
TITLE.

> [{quoted}](name=Parceval,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=9TTYIrcJ,comment-id=0023,timestamp=2016-03-26T23:33:49.909+0000)

> As a proponent of solo queue, what problems do you currently see that you believe it will fix?

The main problem with DQ is that many Solo players HATE playing against premades, which DQ has made larger access to. With premades likely having better synergy and communication, the Solo team feels cheated that they are forced into a disadvantage before the game even began. For 2-4 man premades, the 1-3 Solo players forced to team up with them would feel like outcasts and little to no communication between them and the premades, plus trolling/griefing/verbally abusing is likely to happen against the Solo players, especially if it is a 3-4 man premade. If the Solo(s) make even the smallest mistake, chances are the entire premade will bitch at them.

Its like 5 random UFC fighters forced to fight an entire football team at the same time.

What Riot is trying to do with Dynamic Q is trying to put wolves(Premades) and lions(Solos) together and forcing them to be friends.

Back then, the only premades you would get are Duos. They were tolerable at best.

What SoloQ could fix(if Riot tries) with some adjustments, is the entire removal of premades, giving the queue the same new champion select system as DQ, while keeping the later around for premades AND solo's(who prefer the challenge). With the support problem, Riot could follow World of Warcraft's example and make the least desirable roles more rewarding via bonus ip, higher chance for hextech items, etc.

> Either u have 5 solos vs 3+2 premades which happens very often in my case, 90% of time leading to a lose. 

This argument has been refuted mutiple times by Riot and it is both within their power and their explicit intention to not allow a random consortium to face a premade.

Instead, the design intention (and what I have experienced personally) is that premades face premades. 

Yes, it's possible that every 1 out of 80 (that's their current rate) game is imbalanced, but generally it's just not true. You have worse odds you're going to get in a car accident everytime you drive. Your lifetime odds of DYING in a car accident are pretty dang similar. At this point, it's not a bone of contention.

It's a perceived issue, but it's simply not there. I understand having frustrating games and looking for an underlying cause it's often easy to point fingers at low hanging fruit. However, it's much more likely that the system changes they've made in Season 6 from AD changes, tower alterations, minion ramping, etc is resulting in games that are more often stomps than close matches. Or least, the stomps are just that much more extreme. This systematic shorting of general gameplay and overall tuning toward extreme matches is more probably the cause than anything to do with dynamic queue.

Your suggestion at the end about bonus IP is spot on, I agree entirely, but that could be applied to DQ, and splitting queues would only exacerbate any queuing issues we're currently experiencing by an order of magnitude.

* Favoritism- I have had games where the JG is in the same group as some other laner and ONLY go to their lane, completely ignoring the rest of the map. I am not caught up. Can someone explain to me why does everyone want solo queue back?

I don't play ranked but these are the complaints as I understand them (anyone feel free to correct me if I'm wrong):

* A team with a larger pre-made group has a significant advantage in coordination and team-work, both due to the ability to use voice chat and the fact that they are less likely to argue with each other due to being friends*. Ideally teams are matched against teams with equal size pre-mades, but this will not always be the case so as to prevent absurd queue times.
* This advantage creates an unfair match-up when compared to a team of solo-players. This can be adjusted for by matching pre-made groups up against higher skill players, but this leads to the sense that "team" players are of a higher rank than "solo" players. A solo player probably put in a lot of hard work to reach their rank, yet a team player reaches the same elo despite lower skill simply by taking advantage of the benefits of team play.
* Lastly, since players are significantly less likely to be unpleasant towards people they actually know, rather than random strangers on the internet, there is the accusation that pre-mades are more toxic. Having one or two players on your team that are "on your side" makes it much easier to blame a poor game on that random stranger.

I WANT SOLO QUEUE!
